intro: Omphalodes persica, commonly known as Persian globeflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to regions of Central Asia and the Middle East. It is characterized by its striking, globe-shaped flower heads composed of numerous small, pink or purple petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are hairy and arranged alternately along the stem. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for rock gardens and alpine settings.
